thinkers.name: Michael Levin
thinkers.context: Co-author; primary investigator on xenobots, synthetic morphology, and basal cognition; explores goal-directed behavior in biological systems at multiple scales.

thinkers.name: Wesley P. Clawson
thinkers.context: Co-author; contributes to synthetic biology and novel organism engineering.

thinkers.name: Hans Spemann
thinkers.context: Early developmental biologist who understood the fundamental link between cognition (mind) and morphogenesis (body).

thinkers.name: Alan Turing
thinkers.context: Early theorist who recognized connections between morphogenesis and computation.

thinkers.name: Giovanni Pezzulo
thinkers.context: Researcher exploring predictive processing and goal-directed behavior in biological systems.

thinkers.name: William James
thinkers.context: Defined intelligence as the ability to reach the same goal through different means.

thinkers.name: Paul Lyon
thinkers.context: Contributor to emerging field of basal cognition investigating roots of intelligence in pre-neural forms.

thinkers.name: Fred Keijzer
thinkers.context: Researcher in basal cognition and unfamiliar forms of intelligence.

thinkers.name: Douglas Blackiston
thinkers.context: Researcher producing xenobots and studying novel morphologies from frog cells.

thinkers.name: Eörs Szathmáry
thinkers.context: Theorist on evolution and multi-scale competency architecture.

thinkers.name: David Power
thinkers.context: Researcher on learning processes in evolution and competency architecture.

thinkers.name: Robert Rosen
thinkers.context: Theorist on bioengineering and evolution working in living medium.

thinkers.name: Jonas
thinkers.context: Researcher addressing challenges of predicting stable outcomes at large scales from cellular observations.

thinkers.name: Warren P. Clawson
thinkers.context: Co-author of the paper; contributes to framework on engineering novel bodies and minds.

thinkers.name: Karl Friston
thinkers.context: Contributor to theories of active inference and free energy principle; cited for work on cognitive dynamics beyond neurons.

thinkers.name: Daniel Dennett
thinkers.context: Acknowledged for contributions to philosophical discussions on consciousness and intentionality.

thinkers.name: Jacob von Uexküll
thinkers.context: Developer of Umwelt concept; foundational work on organism-specific environmental perception.

thinkers.name: Nick Bostrom
thinkers.context: Cited for work on human enhancement and transhumanist perspectives.

thinkers.name: Christopher Fields
thinkers.context: Collaborator on morphological coordination and scale-free biology concepts.

thinkers.name: Joshua Bongard
thinkers.context: Co-developer of xenobots and reconfigurable organisms; expert in bio-hybrid systems.

thinkers.name: Rodney Brooks
thinkers.context: Developer of subsumption architecture; foundational work in autonomous robotics control.

thinkers.name: Norbert Wiener
thinkers.context: Founder of cybernetics; seminal work on feedback and goal-directed systems.

thinkers.name: Olaf Witkowski
thinkers.context: Acknowledged contributor to discussions on living systems and computation.

thinkers.name: Elizaveta Solomonova
thinkers.context: Contributor to Diverse Intelligences community discussions.

thinkers.name: Bill Duane
thinkers.context: Acknowledged collaborator on diverse intelligences research.

thinkers.name: Richard Mills
thinkers.context: Contributes to evolutionary connectionism and developmental memory.

concepts.name: Teleonomy
concepts.context: Central concept: the ability of systems to reach specific observable states (goals) through different means and varying degrees of reliability and competency, independent of substrate or origin.

concepts.name: Basal Cognition
concepts.context: Emerging field investigating the roots of intelligence and problem-solving in ancient, pre-neural forms and non-traditional embodiments.

concepts.name: Plasticity
concepts.context: The capacity of biological systems to reach similar forms and functions despite radical perturbations to circumstances, composition, or internal components.

concepts.name: Morphogenesis
concepts.context: The process by which cellular collectives self-organize into complex anatomical structures; now understood as a collective intelligence problem.

concepts.name: Competency Architecture
concepts.context: Hypothesis that life exploits a hierarchical, multi-scale system where subsystems at each level exhibit their own goal-directedness (teleonomic behavior) in diverse problem spaces.

concepts.name: Xenobots
concepts.context: Novel proto-organisms assembled from dissociated frog skin cells; exhibit spontaneous motility, repair, kinematic self-replication, and goal-directed behaviors without genetic modification.

concepts.name: Synthetic Morphology
concepts.context: Field of engineering novel living forms by combining evolved and designed components to explore anatomical and behavioral possibility spaces.

concepts.name: Collective Intelligence
concepts.context: Problem-solving capability that emerges from the cooperation and competition of multiple goal-directed agents or subunits.

concepts.name: Cyborg
concepts.context: Hybrid systems integrating biological tissues with engineered inorganic interfaces through closed-loop controls enabling mutual influence.

concepts.name: Hybrots
concepts.context: Synthetic living machines composed of neural cultures coupled via closed-loop techniques to physical robots or virtual environments.

concepts.name: Homeostatic Setpoint
concepts.context: The target state or preferred condition that a biological system works to maintain or achieve through goal-directed behavior.

concepts.name: Homeostatic Loops
concepts.context: Self-regulating mechanisms by which systems expend energy to attain and maintain specific preferred states regarding information, prediction error, metabolism, and anatomy.

concepts.name: Anatomical Morphospace
concepts.context: The multidimensional space representing all possible anatomical configurations that biological systems can navigate and explore.

concepts.name: Problem Space
concepts.context: The multidimensional space of variables and states in which a system operates to solve problems and pursue goals; extends beyond physical 3D movement.

concepts.name: Ectopic Organ
concepts.context: An organ or tissue placed in an abnormal anatomical location; demonstrates biological plasticity when such organs develop correctly and integrate with the nervous system.

concepts.name: Self-assembly
concepts.context: Process by which biological components autonomously organize into complex structures, potentially guided by higher-level goals rather than micromanaged.

concepts.name: Regenerative Medicine
concepts.context: Medical field seeking to induce cellular collectives to build desired structures through understanding morphogenetic processes and teleonomic behavior.

concepts.name: Chimeras
concepts.context: Organisms or systems mixing biological components from diverse sources; reveals continuous nature of categories often thought binary and tests generalizability of biological principles.

concepts.name: Inverse Problem
concepts.context: The challenge that because genome-to-anatomy relationships are highly indirect, it is difficult to compute which DNA changes produce desired bodily changes.

concepts.name: Credit Assignment Problem
concepts.context: Challenge in machine learning and evolution of determining which subunits to modify to reduce error given environmental feedback.

concepts.name: Intelligence
concepts.context: Capacity to reach the same goal through different means; extends beyond brains to cellular collectives navigating various problem spaces.

concepts.name: Developmental Bioelectricity
concepts.context: Electrical networks in all somatic cells executing homeostatic loops and controlling cell behaviors in anatomical morphospace, isomorphic to neural computation.

concepts.name: Ion Channels
concepts.context: Molecular structures enabling bioelectric dynamics across cell membranes; fundamental to cellular problem-solving and collective coordination.

concepts.name: Gap Junctions
concepts.context: Cellular connections enabling bioelectric coupling and information exchange between cells in multicellular systems.

concepts.name: Neural Decoding
concepts.context: Process of extracting information from neural electrical activity to reconstruct intended movements or states; now applied to non-neural cells.

concepts.name: Diverse Intelligence
concepts.context: Emerging field recognizing and studying multiple forms of goal-directed problem-solving intelligence across diverse embodiments and substrates.

concepts.name: Artificial Life
concepts.context: Field exploring life-like properties in chemical, metabolic, and computational spaces through simulation and engineering.

concepts.name: Cybernetics
concepts.context: Framework for understanding goal-directed behavior, control, and communication in animals and machines; substrate-independent and unified.

concepts.name: Agency
concepts.context: The capacity and property of being a goal-directed agent; now understood as continuous spectrum rather than binary property.

concepts.name: Cellular Competency
concepts.context: The goal-directed problem-solving abilities exhibited by cells and cellular collectives in navigating physiological and morphological spaces.

concepts.name: Emergent Morphogenesis
concepts.context: Emergence of anatomical forms and behaviors from collective cell behavior rather than direct genetic instruction; reveals goals arise through system dynamics.

concepts.name: Moral Worth
concepts.context: Property used to evaluate ethical status of entities; paper argues competency in pursuing goals is more fundamental than origin or composition.

concepts.name: Coarse-Graining
concepts.context: Process of abstracting from molecular-level details to identify meaningful higher-level anatomical and physiological set points and goals.

concepts.name: Self
concepts.context: Coherent goal-directed entity maintaining identity through time; can be implemented in diverse substrates from neurons to cellular collectives.

concepts.name: Cancer
concepts.context: Pathological condition representing failure of normal teleonomic coordination; understanding morphogenetic goals may enable treatment.

concepts.name: Regeneration
concepts.context: Capacity to rebuild missing body parts through coordinated goal-directed behavior of cellular collectives; demonstrates remarkable plasticity and competency.

concepts.name: Neuroprosthetics
concepts.context: Devices interfacing with nervous systems to enable control of novel effectors or sensing of novel modalities, demonstrating brain plasticity.

concepts.name: Cooperation
concepts.context: Goal-directed coordination among multiple agents or subsystems; enables complex multi-scale competency architectures.

concepts.name: Evo-Devo
concepts.context: Field studying evolution through lens of developmental processes; expanding toward bio-robo and synthetic morphology.

concepts.name: Tame
concepts.context: To understand and manage gradual changes in cognition during development from egg cell to complex goal-driven cognitive self.

concepts.name: Cognition
concepts.context: Redefined as a spectrum property present in all living systems exhibiting goal-directed behavior; not limited to nervous systems.

concepts.name: Umwelt
concepts.context: Von Uexküll's concept of organism-specific environmental perception; extended to multi-scale biological organization.

concepts.name: Affordances
concepts.context: Action possibilities available to systems; molecular pathways and biophysical dynamics serve as affordances for competition and cooperation across biological levels.

concepts.name: Extended Mind
concepts.context: Cognitive processes extend beyond individual organisms; extended to multi-scale biological systems.

concepts.name: Bioelectricity
concepts.context: Voltage patterns across cell membranes serving as information carrier for anatomical control; distinct from action potentials.

concepts.name: Bottom-Up Control
concepts.context: Manipulating system behavior through direct modification of components; often produces suboptimal or harmful outcomes.

concepts.name: Downward Causation
concepts.context: Macroscopic goal states influencing component behavior; more efficient than bottom-up approaches for complex systems.

concepts.name: Compassion
concepts.context: Proposed basis for future ethics; proportional to teleonomic capacity rather than genetic similarity.

concepts.name: Emergence
concepts.context: How collective intelligences develop morphological and behavioral goals not shaped by evolutionary history.

concepts.name: Competency
concepts.context: Degree and complexity a system can handle in pursuing goal states; defines position on cognition continuum.

concepts.name: Consciousness
concepts.context: Proposed as continuous property related to goal-directedness; potentially present in diverse biological systems.

concepts.name: Modularity
concepts.context: Organization of systems into semi-independent modules; relevant to evolutionary innovation and control strategies.

concepts.name: Evolvability
concepts.context: Ability of systems to generate adaptive variation; related to genetic regulation and developmental flexibility.

concepts.name: Developmental Memory
concepts.context: Capacity of developmental systems to remember and maintain phenotypic states across generations.

concepts.name: Autopoiesis
concepts.context: Self-organizing and self-maintaining properties of living systems; foundational concept for life definitions.

concepts.name: Active Inference
concepts.context: Cognitive processes involving active prediction and model-based control of environment.

concepts.name: Free Energy Principle
concepts.context: Framework explaining how living systems minimize surprise through active inference and embodiment.

concepts.name: Bayesian Inference
concepts.context: Framework for understanding how systems compute optimal behavior given uncertainty.

concepts.name: Developmental Plasticity
concepts.context: Developmental systems' capacity to generate diverse phenotypes from same genotype.

concepts.name: Scale-Free Cognition
concepts.context: Cognitive properties present across biological organizational scales from molecular to organismal.

concepts.name: Care
concepts.context: Proposed ethical foundation; agents capable of teleonomic action have moral standing proportional to their capacity.

concepts.name: Persuadability
concepts.context: Spectrum from brute-force physical manipulation to rational argument; determines optimal control strategy.

concepts.name: Agential Material
concepts.context: Materials composed of agentic components; collaborative relationship between crafter and material.

concepts.name: Morphological Coordination
concepts.context: Common ancestral function unifying neural and non-neural signaling in form control.

concepts.name: Sensory Substitution And Augmentation
concepts.context: Technologies providing novel sensory modalities; demonstrate neural plasticity in adaptation.

concepts.name: Individualism
concepts.context: Definition of what constitutes an individual organism; extended to include engineered and chimeric systems.

concepts.name: Pattern Regulation
concepts.context: How biological systems maintain and regulate spatial patterns despite perturbations.

concepts.name: Gene Regulatory Networks
concepts.context: Network of genes regulating each other; exhibits memory and pattern-formation capabilities.

concepts.name: Hierarchically Mechanistic Mind
concepts.context: Evolutionary systems theory of brain and behavior emphasizing hierarchical organization.

concepts.name: Cognitive Lens
concepts.context: Analytical tools for understanding cognition in developmental and regenerative systems.

frameworks.name: Multi-Scale Competency Architecture
frameworks.creator: Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Hypothesis that life exploits hierarchical nested goal-directedness at multiple levels enabling robust problem-solving and adaptive evolution.

frameworks.name: Cybernetic Framework
frameworks.creator: Norbert Wiener
frameworks.context: Substrate-independent framework for understanding goal-directed behavior in systems; applicable to animals and machines alike.

frameworks.name: Homeostatic Loop Model
frameworks.context: Framework conceptualizing systems as maintaining preferred states through sensing, memory, and corrective action.

frameworks.name: Brain-Body-Environment Schema
frameworks.context: Traditional framework for understanding agents; now extended to unconventional embodiments in bioengineering.

frameworks.name: Morphospace Navigation
frameworks.context: Framework treating morphogenesis as navigating through multidimensional space of possible anatomical configurations.

frameworks.name: Teleonomic Framework
frameworks.context: Unified framework for comparing and understanding diverse agents based on goal-directed behavior rather than origin or composition.

frameworks.name: Multiscale Competency Architecture
frameworks.creator: Michael Levin et al.
frameworks.context: Generalization of subsumption architecture where each layer is an agentic system; enables robots with flexible, adaptable properties.

frameworks.name: Subsumption Architecture
frameworks.creator: Rodney Brooks
frameworks.context: Layered control system for autonomous robotics; foundational approach generalized by multiscale competency architecture.

frameworks.name: Technological Approach To Mind Everywhere (TAME)
frameworks.creator: Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Experimentally-grounded framework for understanding diverse bodies and minds; enables comparison of heterogeneous intelligences.

frameworks.name: Xenobots
frameworks.creator: Joshua Bongard and Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Synthetic living machines created from reprogrammed tadpole cells; demonstrate collaborative relationship between designer intent and cellular competency.

frameworks.name: Cybernetics
frameworks.creator: Norbert Wiener
frameworks.context: Science of control and communication in animals and machines; foundational framework for understanding goal-directed systems.

frameworks.name: Evolutionary Transitions In Individuality (ETIs)
frameworks.context: Framework for understanding major transitions where new levels of organization emerge with novel collective properties.

frameworks.name: Free-Energy Approach To Pattern Regulation
frameworks.creator: Karl Friston and Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Mathematical framework understanding how systems minimize prediction error in morphological regulation.

frameworks.name: Variational Ecology
frameworks.context: Physics-based approach extending variational free energy principle to ecological and living systems.

frameworks.name: Evolutionary Connectionism
frameworks.context: Framework integrating evo-devo, evo-eco, and evolutionary transitions through connectionist principles.

institutions.name: Allen Discovery Center at Tufts University
institutions.context: Research center where Michael Levin and Wesley Clawson work on xenobots and synthetic morphology.

institutions.name: Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering at Harvard University
institutions.context: Bioengineering institute where Michael Levin conducts research on synthetic biology and novel organisms.

institutions.name: Linnean Society of London
institutions.context: Publisher of the Biological Journal where this paper appears.

institutions.name: Linnean Society
institutions.context: Hosted special issue on teleonomy and meeting on novel bioengineered systems; publisher of this paper.

institutions.name: Levin Lab
institutions.context: Research group led by Michael Levin focusing on developmental bioelectricity and synthetic bioengineering.

institutions.name: Diverse Intelligences community
institutions.context: Network of researchers exploring varied forms of intelligence and cognition across biological systems.

institutions.name: Templeton World Charity Foundation (TWCF)
institutions.context: Funding organization supporting research on fundamental questions about life and consciousness.

institutions.name: John Templeton Foundation
institutions.context: Funding source for research on existential questions and novel approaches to understanding life.

institutions.name: Harvard University
institutions.context: Referenced as publisher of extended organism work.

institutions.name: MIT Press
institutions.context: Publisher of artificial life and computational biology materials.

questions.question: What computations, algorithms or dynamics enable cellular collectives to respond adaptively, reaching the same form and function despite radical induced changes of circumstances?
questions.context: Fundamental question about biological plasticity and the nature of developmental programs underlying adaptation to perturbation.

questions.question: What is the relationship between the genome and anatomy?
questions.context: Core question about how genetic information relates to phenotypic form; complicated by chimaeric organisms and novel morphologies.

questions.question: What mechanisms allow biology to exhibit robustness and plasticity simultaneously, enabling adaptive, coherent organisms to arise in novel circumstances?
questions.context: Asks how biological systems maintain fidelity while remaining adaptable; central to understanding morphogenesis.

questions.question: What aspects of biological structure enabled mind gradually to develop and expand?
questions.context: Fundamental question linking evolution of cognition to physical structure; addresses mind-body problem.

questions.question: How to induce collectives of cells to build one structure rather than another?
questions.context: Practical question underlying regenerative medicine and bioengineering applications; requires understanding morphogenetic goals.

questions.question: When we combine living material with electronics and computer software, where should we draw the line between 'machine' and 'organism'?
questions.context: Questions whether sharp boundaries exist; argues they do not and proposes teleonomy as better organizing principle.

questions.question: What would be the minimal axes for the space of all possible teleonomic agents?
questions.context: Seeks to identify fundamental dimensions for comparing and classifying diverse goal-directed systems.

questions.question: How can we recognize, quantify and compare teleonomic agents in radically diverse embodiments?
questions.context: Asks for frameworks and methods to understand intelligence across unfamiliar implementations.

questions.question: Can neurons from modalities such as vision be trained in external motor control, or are cortical regions 'frozen' by evolution?
questions.context: Questions flexibility of neural tissue organization and implications for artificial chimaeras.

questions.question: What are the implications of embracing the space of possible beings for terminology, conceptual frameworks, research programmes and ethics?
questions.context: Asks about consequences of moving beyond natural kinds toward continuous spectrum of possible organisms.

questions.question: Where do the anatomical and behavioral goals of xenobots originate if they were not directly selected for over aeons?
questions.context: Questions source of teleonomic goals in novel organisms; suggests emergence from laws of form and mathematics.

questions.question: How does evolution capitalize on the laws of physics and computation to generalize so well from specific examples to highly diverse possible instantiations?
questions.context: Fundamental question about evolutionary search efficiency and generalization; central to understanding innovation.

questions.question: How does teleonomy potentiate the evolutionary search for yet larger teleonomic systems?
questions.context: Key to understanding hierarchical emergence of goal-directed systems and major evolutionary transitions.

questions.question: Can the notion of external environment (Umwelt) be extended to a multi-scale concept?
questions.context: Seeks to generalize ecological concepts to molecular and cellular scales; bridges multiple organizational levels.

questions.question: What is the relationship or overlap between the sets demarcated by 'life' and 'cognition'?
questions.context: Central question about whether all living things are cognitive and whether cognition defines life.

questions.question: Are all living things cognitive, given that all components appear to be teleonomic agents?
questions.context: Challenges traditional boundaries between animate and inanimate; philosophical implications for consciousness.

questions.question: What is a useful definition of 'life'?
questions.context: Urgent given that teleonomic agents can be produced by engineering with organic or inorganic parts.

questions.question: How can we develop a semiotics of synthetic agents and their Umwelten?
questions.context: Seeks frameworks for understanding meaning-making in artificial and hybrid biological systems.

questions.question: How can we develop ways of manipulating biological systems via communication and motivation, rather than bottom-up control?
questions.context: Practical and ethical question about more humane and effective biomedical intervention strategies.

questions.question: Can we develop artificial neural networks whose output determines machines that solve problems rather than specific solutions?
questions.context: Seeks to replicate evolutionary learning and generalization capacity in machine learning architectures.

questions.question: Where do goals come from in the first place?
questions.context: Fundamental question addressed by studying synthetic creatures as empirical model systems.

questions.question: How does one prosecute a 50% cyborg for its misdeeds?
questions.context: Practical legal and ethical question arising from emergence of chimeric and enhanced beings.

questions.question: What is the minimal amount of active compassion or functional caring that defines a human being?
questions.context: Seeks new basis for moral categorization beyond genetics or anatomy; future-oriented ethical question.

questions.question: What defines a self?
questions.context: Fundamental question addressed through teleonomy; requires general framework encompassing diverse agents.

questions.question: How will creatures in multidimensional cognitive space relate to each other?
questions.context: Ethical question about future interactions between beings with diverse types and amounts of cognitive capacity.

questions.question: Will intellectual property systems developed for passive materials be suitable for agential materials?
questions.context: Practical question about legal frameworks for collaborative creativity with goal-directed matter.

questions.question: How can we avoid ethical lapses toward designed beings similar to historical mistreatment of unfamiliar groups?
questions.context: Critical future-oriented ethics question about moral consideration of non-natural agents.

questions.question: What does a new ethics of life as it can be look like?
questions.context: Central question for developing moral frameworks appropriate to engineered and hybrid biological systems.

questions.question: Could there have been very early life forms that were not teleonomic?
questions.context: Questions whether teleonomy is necessary or contingent property of life; addresses life's origin.

questions.question: Could current efforts at minimal synthetic life clarify the relationship between teleonomy and physics?
questions.context: Seeks empirical approaches to foundational questions about life and physical law.

questions.question: How can we determine the optimal level of teleonomy in objects around us?
questions.context: Practical question for scientists managing complex systems; core cognitive task for navigating environments.

_metadata.title: Biological Journal of the Linnean Society, 2023, 139, 457–486. With 8 figures.
